content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: E-Jay
Role: Mathematics Researcher
Other Information: About Myself: 
I have mathematical knowledge up to graduate level.

Current interests:
(1) coding: mainly Python
(2) machine learning and artificial intelligence
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.

Define highly technical or specialized abbreviations in full before using them.```

parts: Turn this infographic into a fully functional, self-contained webpage that is mobile-responsive. Correct any mistakes you spot. Make it highly readable and easy to follow.

**Planning a syllabus and curriculum**

I’m working on creating structured course outlines using guidelines like weekly topics, learning goals, and mini-projects. For example, I could draft a syllabus for a 12-week "Intro to Python" course or suggest unit themes for a World History class. This is just a starting point I'll refine later.

**Providing constructive parent feedback**

I can draft feedback for parents with a supportive and encouraging tone. For example, I could use email templates to highlight a child's progress, such as improvement in math, while gently pointing out areas needing attention, like homework submission. It's important the tone feels partnership-focused and constructive.

**Inspecting text for AI tools**

I need to review the text for each box: For the first, I'll mention Google Gemini with a "Sign In" prompt. Then, Google NotebookLM, highlighting document uploads with a "Try It" button. Lastly, Google Workspace Labs, noting the "Labs" icon and a "Join Waitlist" option. I’ll make sure everything matches up right.

**Starting with free tools**

For getting started with free tools, here’s a quick overview: The first box introduces Google Gemini, offering an AI chat partner for ideas and content. The second highlights Google NotebookLM, where you can upload your personal documents to create a custom AI expert. The third details Google Workspace Labs, with experimental in-app features.

**Finalizing teacher’s guide**

The title is set: "Teacher’s Guide to Free Google AI Tools: Your New Teaching Assistant." Now I just need to craft a bottom strip with a critical reminder. It’s important to emphasize that these tools are accessible freely for teachers and can be invaluable for improving classroom productivity.

**Designing a functional mobile-responsive webpage**

The reminder is clear: AI is a tool, not a teacher. Always double-check AI content and ensure your students' privacy. Now, I need to create a clean, mobile-responsive webpage. I'll focus on readability by using structured headings, sections, and CSS grid/flex for responsiveness, avoiding external assets.

**Fixing minor text and formatting errors**

It looks like there are a few things to clean up: I'll change "NotebookLM.google" to "notebooklm.google.com". For "Join Waitlist/Enable", rephrase it to "Join waitlist / enable". Then, I'll fix inconsistent punctuation like "Labs" vs. "workspace labs" and adjust "Grounded AI from YOUR Sources" for emphasis. Also, for clarity, I’ll use "Google Gemini."

**Creating a clean and mobile-responsive HTML structure**

For a static, mobile-friendly design, I’ll put together the structure with clear semantics. I'll start with the basic HTML, setting up a responsive viewport and defining the structure with sections for tool cards and important content. In the CSS, I’ll use grid for responsive columns so the layout adapts to different screen sizes. The UI will adjust automatically, and I can add disclaimers directly to the content.

**Building a self-contained, readable webpage**

I’ll start by creating the HTML structure with `<h2>` for article titles, card-like sections using `<div>` with .tool-card, and examples inside `<blockquote>`. I'll ensure everything is internal, with no external fonts or icons, and make the design mobile-responsive. Using system fonts ensures fast loading with a consistent look. I'll make sure the line-height and font sizing enhance readability while keeping the design compact.

I’ll output the code and minimal explanation.

**Refining text for readability and consistency**

I’ll adjust the text carefully, starting with the title: “Teacher's Guide to Free Google AI Tools: Your New Teaching Assistant” to ensure compatibility with straight ASCII apostrophes. Next, I’ll rephrase and standardize phrases like "in your web browser" instead of "via web browser". Also, I’ll fix capitalization and spelling inconsistencies across tool descriptions for better clarity, and update example prompts for readability. Then I'll continue with the rest of the content, arranging and correcting all text as needed.

**Reworking content for improvements and readability**

I'll add a comma to this example: "Create a 10-question multiple-choice quiz based on this document, with an answer key." I'll adjust the tool descriptions to ensure clarity, like specifying critical thinking in discussion questions for Gemini. For each section, I’ll emphasize AI's role and add reminders to personalize feedback. I’ll also include a top-of-page summary about AI's role as a tool, not a teacher, and ensure the example prompts are clearly highlighted with background color for readability.

entries.title: Google NotebookLM | AI Research Tool & Thinking Partner
